verses.verse: Therefore the LORD has (Jer. 31:28; 44:27) kept the disaster in mind, and brought it upon us; for (Neh. 9:33) the LORD our God is righteous in all the works which He does, though we have not obeyed His voice.

And now, O Lord our God, (Ex. 32:11; 1 Kin. 8:51; Neh. 1:10) who brought Your people out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand, and made Yourself (Ex. 14:18; Neh. 9:10; Jer. 32:20) a name, as it is this day—we have sinned, we have done wickedly!

“O Lord, (1 Sam. 12:7; Ps. 31:1; Mic. 6:4, 5) according to all Your righteousness, I pray, let Your anger and Your fury be turned away from Your city Jerusalem, (Ps. 87:1-3; Dan. 9:20; Joel 3:17; Zech. 8:3) Your holy mountain; because for our sins, (Ex. 20:5) and for the iniquities of our fathers, (Ps. 122:6; Jer. 29:7; Lam. 2:16) Jerusalem and Your people (Ps. 79:4) are a reproach to all those around us.

Now therefore, our God, hear the prayer of Your servant, and his supplications, (Num. 6:24-26; Ps. 80:3, 7, 19) and (Lam. 5:18) for the Lord’s sake cause Your face to shine on Your sanctuary, ((John 16:24)) which is desolate.

(Is. 37:17) O my God, incline Your ear and hear; open Your eyes (Ex. 3:7) and see our desolations, and the city (Jer. 25:29) which is called by Your name; for we do not present our supplications before You because of our righteous deeds, but because of Your great mercies.
O Lord, hear! O Lord, forgive! O Lord, listen and act! Do not delay for Your own sake, my God, for Your city and Your people are called by Your name.”

(The Seventy-Weeks Prophecy) Now while I was speaking, praying, and confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel, and presenting my supplication before the LORD my God for the holy mountain of my God,

yes, while I was speaking in prayer, the man (Dan. 8:16; Luke 1:19, 26) Gabriel, whom I had seen in the vision at the beginning, being caused to fly swiftly, reached me about the time of the evening offering.
And he informed me, and talked with me, and said, “O Daniel, I have now come forth to give you skill to understand.

At the beginning of your supplications the command went out, and I have come to tell you, for you are greatly (Dan. 10:11, 19) beloved; therefore (Matt. 24:15) consider the matter, and understand the vision:

“Seventy weeks are determined For your people and for your holy city, To finish the transgression, To make an end of sins, (2 Chr. 29:24; (Is. 53:10); Acts 10:43; (Rom. 5:10); Heb. 9:12, 14) To make reconciliation for iniquity, (Rev. 14:6) To bring in everlasting righteousness, To seal up vision and prophecy, (Ps. 45:7) And to anoint the Most Holy.

“Know therefore and understand, That from the going forth of the command To restore and build Jerusalem Until (Luke 2:1, 2; John 1:41; 4:25) Messiah (Is. 55:4) the Prince, There shall be seven weeks and sixty-two weeks; The street shall be built again, and the wall, Even in troublesome times.

“And after the sixty-two weeks ((Is. 53:8); Matt. 27:50; Mark 9:12; 15:37; (Luke 23:46; 24:26); John 19:30; Acts 8:32) Messiah shall be cut off, ((1 Pet. 2:21)) but not for Himself; And (Matt. 22:7) the people of the prince who is to come (Matt. 24:2; Mark 13:2; Luke 19:43, 44) Shall destroy the city and the sanctuary. The end of it shall be with a flood, And till the end of the war desolations are determined.

Then he shall confirm (Is. 42:6) a covenant with ((Matt. 26:28)) many for one week; But in the middle of the week He shall bring an end to sacrifice and offering. And on the wing of abominations shall be one who makes desolate, (Dan. 11:36) Even until the consummation, which is determined, Is poured out on the desolate.”

(Vision of the Glorious Man) In the third year of Cyrus king of Persia a message was revealed to Daniel, whose (Dan. 1:7) name was called Belteshazzar. The message was true, but the appointed time was long; and he understood the message, and had understanding of the vision.
In those days I, Daniel, was mourning three full weeks.
I ate no pleasant food, no meat or wine came into my mouth, nor did I anoint myself at all, till three whole weeks were fulfilled.
Now on the twenty-fourth day of the first month, as I was by the side of the great river, that is, the Tigris,
I lifted my eyes and looked, and behold, a certain man clothed in (Ezek. 9:2; 10:2) linen, whose waist was (Rev. 1:13; 15:6) girded with gold of Uphaz!

His body was like beryl, his face like the appearance of lightning, his eyes like torches of fire, his arms and feet like burnished bronze in color, ((Rev. 1:15)) and the sound of his words like the voice of a multitude.
And I, Daniel, alone saw the vision, for the men who were with me did not see the vision; but a great terror fell upon them, so that they fled to hide themselves.
